title: The $58,000 tree that Hamptons residents are fighting to install
description: Forget mega yachts and mansions, if you can't afford a $95,000 tree, you are no longer up to Hamptons standards.
content:
Forget mega yachts and mansions, the latest Hamptons status symbol is found in the garden.

A $58,000 shrub has become the latest must-have for wealthy residents in the elite corner of New York's East End.

The Hindu-Pan topiary sparked a furious bidding war earlier this Spring, according to Marders, the go-to garden center in Bridgehampton.

It is densely held and slow-growing, making it perfect for homeowners looking to make a statement without excessive upkeep.

Charlie Marder, who opened Marders with his wife Kathleen in 1975, told the Daily Mail that, while the price sounds extravagant, it reflects the cost and complexity of moving a 60 to 80-year-old specimen.

'It's not just a tree, it's a time capsule. It represents decades of growth,' Marders said.

Marders gathers the and other specialist trees from across the country, some costing an eye-watering $95,000.

He won’t sell them to customers without a property inspection, to ensure the garden has enough space and sunlight for the precious tree to thrive.

If the garden doesn’t make the cut, Marders said he has been known to reject clients.

He revealed that five eager shoppers fought over a $58,000 Hindu-Pan topiary earlier this year.

For anyone tempted to cash in on the trend, one tree is still on offer offer: A 65-foot crepe myrtle for $95,000.

Marders explained that the generic manicured lawns and neatly trimmed hedges once synonymous with the wealthy enclave are on their way out.

His store currently sells a large selection of rocks - glacial, architectural, archaeological and some unusual mined stones that are displayed in the garden yard and often incorporated into their projects.

Marders explained that people 'want gardens that make sense,' not just generic landscaping.

'Residents of the Hamptons want outdoor spaces that are aligned with their home's architecture, their geographic location, their environmental beliefs and the kind of lifestyle they are seeking outdoors,' he said.

He explained people began really prioritizing garden spaces in the 1970s, when gourmet food became a norm and when entertaining moved into the outdoor space.

The fascination has been accelerated following the pandemic because people were home all the time and started to see their property differently, Marders explained.

Another hot commodity in Hamptons gardens this summer is Nassella grass, per The Cut.

Residents have reportedly been requesting Nassella - a hair-thin grass with golden hay-like tips, from their landscapers in their droves.

It has now upstaged the once-popular Japanese forest grass, Hakonechloa.

Pinewood Ferennial Gardens in the North Folk anticipates 9,000 plants to be sold by the end of summer.

One customer asked for 600 pots of the precious grass in June. She was told she would have to settle for 80.

‘Trendy designers use something and everybody copies it,’ assistant manager Ken Johnson told The Cut.

Aside from expensive greenery, another landscaping trend in the Hamptons is the ‘longevity garden’.

According to Modern Luxury, longevity gardens go beyond aesthetic - these gardens are tied up in the wellness sphere.

Celebrated landscape architect and LaGuardia Design Group founder Christopher LaGuardia pioneered the concept with his certified nutritionist daughter Charlotte.

Together they are planting gardens designed to ‘support health, vitality and intentional living’.

The gardens feature a combination of antioxidant-packed herbs and layouts that invite mindfulness and movement.

Nothing screams 'The Hamptons' more than a crossover between luxury landscaping and ‘wellness’.

Charlie Marder, the owner of Marders, who opened the business in 1975, said the price reflects the cost and complexity of moving a 60-year-old specimen. The topiary, which is densely held and slow-growing, is ideal for homeowners looking to make a statement without excessive upkeep. Marderers selects rare trees from across the country, some costing $95,000. He won't sell them without a property inspection to ensure the garden has enough space and sunlight for the tree to thrive. The trend of 'longevity gardens' in the Hamptons is also gaining popularity, with enthusiasts reportedly requesting hair-thin grass with golden hay-like tips from their landscapers.

scraped_sources.text:
.
The Grass
Nassella is the hair-thin grass with golden haylike tips that upstaged the once-hip Japanese forest grass Hakonechloa. The North Fork’s Pinewood Perennial Gardens expects to sell out 9,000 plants by the end of summer. In June, a customer asking for 600 pots had to settle for 80. “Trendy designers use something and everybody copies it,” says assistant manager Ken Johnson.
.
The Fruit
The Japanese muskmelon is imported in limited quantities, and the Ryoma, the highest grade of melon, is especially rare in the U.S. Last summer, only a couple of dozen families out East were able to get their hands on one. Jonathan Bernard of Farm & Forage Market in Southampton expects he’ll have 50 to 100 for sale this year for $300 each.
.
The Tree
A one-of-a-kind specimen tree. Bridgehampton’s Marders sources them from all over the country and requires customers to undergo a home inspection to make sure they have enough space and sunlight. It has been known to turn clients down. This spring, five fought over a $58,000 Hindu-Pan topiary. Available still is a 65-foot crape myrtle for $95,000.
.
The Poultry
Do not show up with white eggs. Anywhere. Pigment is required. The most-coveted eggs produced by Indian Runner ducks can be described as Farrow & Ball Skylight. At Shelter Island’s Sylvester Manor, the farm manager, Arielle Gardner, says there are 40 female ducks. All are named Gary, and their eggs are $6 per half-dozen.
.
The Fishing Pole
The custom-built rods at White Water Outfitters in Hampton Bays convey serious connoisseurship. They are made by Rich Parisen, a 65-year “master rod builder” who learned his trade at the Bergdorf Goodman of bait-and-tackle shops, Altenkirch Precision Outfitters, which, in its heyday, served everyone from Babe Ruth to Billy Joel.
.
The Cutlery
Dereyk Patterson’s custom knives have a two-year waiting list. The work of the East Hampton artisan is prized by chefs such as Jacques Pépin. Each cleaver, slicer, and chef’s knife is made to order, starting at $1,800, and forged in small batches over the course of a month. “I can only do one thing at a time,” he says. That’s roughly ten-to-15 knives a month.
.
The Grill
An Argentine-style wood-burning Parrilla Grill from Northfork Ironworks. In-the-know pitmasters such as Tom Colicchio and Roberta’s Brandon Hoy are fans. In May, seven were delivered to Long Island grillers by ownerBrendan McCarthy, who takes a month to weld the 300-pound pieces himself in the Catskills; 15 more are on a waiting list.
.
The Sauna
Tylö, a make of Swedish saunas, is the brand to have. Bud Handel of East End Spa and Sauna and Wine Cellars has built 11 this year. Orders start at $30,000 for indoor saunas, and an outdoor lodge can cost up to $110,000. Custom designs take three months to complete, at minimum: “Right now, I would not promise a good sauna outdoors built by Labor Day,” Handel says.
.
The Dress
Tiina the Store closed two years ago, but in its place Amagansett gained The Row. The brand’s cotton midi-dress the Anitas is a real flex because it has sold out almost everywhere. “I’m wearing it to my bridal shower in Sag, actually, but it was a bitch to get my hands on,” says Jess Graves, author of the shopping newsletter The Love List.
.
The Outerwear
Marfa Stance’s plain quilted jackets can be personalized with custom collars, hoods, and liners. It’s the Build-a-Bear of Montauk-mom outerwear. “The point is not that they’re cute,” says a personal shopper in town, where they’re sold at Lingua Franca, “but that they’re so distinct other moms can clock you and know you are one of them.”
.
The Car
The original Land Cruiser from Toyota’s FJ series. Icon makes bespoke editions starting at $229,000. “We have about 50 units in the Hamptons area, and interest continues to grow as people resist showing up in a G-Wagon or Cybertruck,” says CEO Jonathan Ward. There’s a waiting list until 2026.
.
The Boat
Megayacht owners telegraph rank by cruising into Duryea’s on a Vanquish, a multi-million-dollar, high-speed day yacht with an aluminum hull that’s the Cybertruck of the water. There are just 35 on Long Island, mostly in Sag Harbor. The motto of the Netherlands-based shipyard is “Not for Everyone.”

argos_summary: In the Hamptons, the latest luxury trend is investing in rare, high‑cost plants that serve as status symbols and low‑maintenance statements, such as a $58,000 Hindu‑Pan topiary and a $95,000 crepe myrtle. Garden designers are moving away from generic lawns toward bespoke, longevity gardens that blend wellness and aesthetics, with popular grasses like Nassella replacing older favorites. Marders, a Bridgehampton nursery, emphasizes careful site assessment before selling these trees, while other local boutiques offer complementary luxury goods—from custom knives and saunas to high‑end grills and yachts—reflecting a broader shift toward curated, experiential outdoor spaces.
